awd_titl_txt: Probing Facet Dependent Properties of Crystalline Nanomaterials and Interactions with Biomolecules using Hybrid AFM

por.por_cntn:
Engineered nanomaterials (ENMs) are usually fabricated with different sizes or morphologies to tailor their surface chemistry and reactivity. The size or shape dependence of surface properties are largely correlated with the surface exposure crystallographic facets or surface atoms (atomic arrays). These different atomic coordination and structural configurations of ENMs surfaces govern the molecular interactions such as adsorption of cations and anions, charge transfer, binding and generation of products or reactive species. This proposal mainly employed scanning probe microscopic techniques to investigate nanomaterial properties at a crystal facet level to unravel the interdependence of material properties and implications on chemical, colloidal, photochemical properties of ENMs as well as their biomolecular interactions. This project involved (1) synthesis and characterization of crystallographic facets and facet distribution of model ENMs (e.g., Cu2O) with different morphologies such as cube, octahedron or pyramid. (2) assessing intrinsic properties at local facet levels including electrochemical, electronic structures and hydrophobicity using high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM), atomic force microscope combined with electrochemical spectrometry (AFM-SECM) and density function theory (DFT) calculations. (3) investigating extrinsic properties at local facet levels including photocatalytic or photochemical properties of Lanthanum Titanium Oxide (La2Ti2O7) and silver nanoparticle’s dissolution behavior. (4) measuring and mapping molecular adsorption, binding and degradation on ENM facets.

The major outcomes of this project are multifaceted and composed of journal publications, professional conference presentations, student research training, proposal writing training, development of new research methods and teaching materials. First, the project results in five journal publications with three under review or preparation. For example, we published photocatalytically reductive defluorination of perfluorooctanoic acid using Pt/La2Ti2O7 nanoplates and demonstrated the single Atom Platinum (Pt) doping and facet dependence of the electronic structure and light absorption of La2Ti2O7. Similar facet-dependent electrochemical and electronic properties of Cu2O of four different shapes (cube, cuboctahedron, octahedron, and rhombic dodecahedron) were discovered using novel AFM and computational methods. The work promoted our understanding of fundamental mechanisms for molecular interactions (e.g., methyl orange) on crystal facets of Cu2O and explained surface-mediated reactions or interfacial processes on metal oxide surfaces. Over the three-year project, three oral and eight poster presentations were delivered at ACS Annual Conference, AGU and EAS Annual Meeting. One PhD student at NJIT has been supported to complete most of the research tasks. Moreover, one master and two undergraduate students and two high school students were involved via various educational programs at NJIT such as Undergraduate Research Innovation (URI), The Garden State LSAMP (Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation) and Army Educational Outreach Program (AEOP). The PhD student also interacted with industrial partners through the NSF INTERN program that facilitated the instrument training in AFM-SECM, which was successfully established at NJIT and utilized for this project. This characterization technique adds unique strength to the NJIT's research infrastructure and regional nanotechnology development. The research activities also promoted the development of novel teaching modules that enhanced both undergraduate and graduate curricula or research training opportunities. For example, the URI students and other student interns were able to learn the use of cyclic voltammetry (CV), electrochemical impedance spectrometry (EIS), kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) and AFM-SECM with the direct training from the supported Ph.D. student. The students also had the opportunity to acquire the computational chemistry skills using DFT’s Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package and COMSOL Multiphysics and evaluated exposed facet properties of Cu2O (e.g., [100], [110] and [111]) and electrochemical reaction dynamics at water/nanomaterial interface. With the acquired new skills and scientific research training, the PhD student also independently worked grant proposals and achieved a student research grant ($5000) from New Jersey Water Resources Research Institute (NJWRRI) that supported his study on novel electrochemical nanomaterials for water remediation. Finally, in addition to the above research experiences and training, other functional faceted nanomaterials such as MXenes (new-fangled 2D transition metal carbide) have been evaluated to explore their surface reactivity and environmental applications such as filtration membrane development. For example, MXenes were evaluated for membrane distillation (MD), poly- and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) electrosorption and degradation. Both experimental and computational approaches have been established to unravel the molecular adsorption and degradation mechanisms for MXenes with different terminated groups (Cl, F, O and OH) on different facets. These research outcomes further improve our understanding of the unique surface properties of engineered nanomaterials and will support the design of functional and sustainable nanomaterials.
